2. 0 3. There was no institutional set for social innovation lab in Sri Lanka

1. 10 - One of the most significant events was the launch of the global Human Development Report 2015 which was by the Policy Unit, supported by the Communications Unit.
2. 12 - One of the most significant external events held in 2015 by the Communications Unit was the launch of the Paths to Progress Publication and documentary which showcases the work of UNDP across Sri Lanka. This was an event which was held with the donor community, the media and the partners.

1. 10
2. 8
3. completion of preperation for the project

1. 10 - Few of the programme events held for this year includes the communication Unit’s support to the Governance and Environment Unit to highlight their work through several media releases, and video documentaries, including support to host the International Water Conference together with the Policy Unit.
2. 8 - One of the significant external events held in this year was the hosting of Sri Lanka first Summit on Foresight and Innovation for Sustainable Human Development. This was held with over 350 participants and hosted with the partnership of new partners such as LirnAsia, Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, Sarvodaya, Ceylon Biscuits Limited [private sector] and global partners such as Pulse Lab, MindLab, myforesight Malaysia etc. This summit initiated the discussion on establishing Sri lanka’s first Social Innovation Lab. The Communications Unit also supported the media and public engagements of the missions of the UNESCO DG, the UN Secretary General and other OHCHR delegations.

1. 8
2. 10
3. Establishment of partnership with the government

1. 8 - Throughout the year, the communications unit has been supporting the programme units on various fronts; providing donor visibility and media coverage on certain projects through press releases, photo stories and newsletters, supporting the policy unit in designing SDG visibility material, and supporting field units to design and showcase their work on the ground.
2. 10 - One of the most significant external events held for this year is the Youth CoLab: National Youth Dialogue on Youth in November 2017. This was held in partnership with the Ministry of Science, technology and research, the Ministry of Digital Infrastructure and Telecommunications and Unilever [private sector] and other partners, with 300 students over a span of 2 days. This paved the way for a more formal partnership between UNDP Sri Lanka, Unilever and the United Nations Global Compact [UNGC] to host a series of high-level private sector forums on Public Private Partnerships to align Businesses with the Sustainable Development Agenda.
3. signed the prodoc with the ministry of science Technology and Research . First project board meeting was conducted. The lab physical structure is being renovated.

1) 5 Joint initiatives established with key stakeholder agencies of the project to conduct IAS baseline assessments. This is the first step to develop and implement pilot projects incorporating ecosystem approach to IAS management 2) IAS National Coordination Committee is functioning with the involvement of key stakeholder agencies. IAS Policy and Strategy has been re-drafted as recommended by the MTR of the project and ready for Cabinet approval. Secretary to the ministry has instructed to include the IAS National Action Plan along with the Policy and Strategy for Cabinet approval. IAS National Action Plan will be finalized within December 2015. National Invasive Species Specialist group was expanded and continuing to provide technical advises. 3) IAS data base is being prepared. Initial arrangements are made ( human and IT resources) to maintain and update the database by national focal point. 4) IAS Act has to be re drafted as recommended by MTR. Process started with the support of a legal consultant and first draft will be available in first quarter of 2016.

1) 10 2) National IAS Policy, Strategy, Action Plan available and approved by the Cabinet. 3) Upgraded IAS Web based data base is up and running. 4) IAS act is prepared and submitted to legal draftsmen department.

1) Eighteen (18) IAS cells have been set up within stakeholder agencies to act as the focal points for implementation of IAS national action plan. Forty (40) district level trainings conducted with the involvement of NGO’s, private firms. Fourteen (14) research grants given to researchers in universities/ research institutions. Eight (8) IAS management pilot projects have been implemented with the support of forest department/wild life conservation department. 2) National IAS Policy, Strategy, Action Plan was approved by the Cabinet and lunched by the H.E. President of Sri Lanka. Awareness built among national, district level on IAS policy. 3) Upgraded IAS web data base has been developed and documents are being uploaded. Officers are available for maintaining the data base. 4) IAS act was prepared and submitted to legal draftsmen department for comments. Few discussions held with legal draftsmen department to address clarifications.
as project is ending March 2017, Indicator target developed for end 2016 will applicable for 2017 as well.

description.narrative:
Reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the use of fossil fuel for thermal energy generation in the Sri Lanka industrial sector
Removal of barriers to the realization of sustainable biomass plantation and adoption of biomassbased energy technologies in Sri Lanka

No of companies operating BETs by endofproject EOP
Number of proposed BET investments by EOP
Total installed capacity and resulting fossil fuel reduction and direct GHG emission reduction of these projects by EOP
share of biomass in energy mix by EOP
Annual fossil fuel consumption reduction starting Year 1
Cumulative GHG emission reduction by EOP

comment.narrative: Limited experience with BETs in industry

At least 12 companies are operating BETs and another 12 companies have detailed feasibility studies completed or started installation of gasifier systems by the end of the project postproject direct emission reduction in particular gasification with total capacity of 257 MWth and 1 MWe resulting in fossil fuel savings of about 295178 GJ annually 4680 MWh of electricity and direct emission reduction cumulative over 10 year lifetime of 252 ktCO2
Indirect emission reduction impacts between 609 bottomup and 1378 ktCO2 top down

There are 10 companies identified as per the inception report who have pledged cofinancing in relation to the outcome 4 It was expected to add more partners
Of these three gasifier systems two Aitken Spence hotels and Apollo Marine International Ltd are in operation and had initiated activities before the project had become operational The plantation companies listed however are more concerned about implementing fuelwood plantations and improving supply chains Almost all the tea processing factories listed now use biomass but for drying purposes not as gasifiers The industrial sector Brandix has implemented a new plant but not with biomass gasifier
There are six other entities too who were mentioned in the inception report as probable candidates Of them one company Lion Brewery is already considering installing a biomass run plant but not opting for gasifier technology
However there are a number of other companies that have already installed and some more have planned to introduce the BETs for thermal energy requirements during the project period without project interventions Majority of them are not Gasifiers as the project has proposed It is noted that the industry prefers other technologies direct fired boilers industrial heaters over gasifiers to meet their thermal needs Therefore project needs to review the technology selection to support industry requirements
This concern was highlighted at the project core group meeting as well as the last steering committee meeting and it was suggested to take up the matter at the MTR time and propose appropriate changes to reflect the changed baseline situation and follow the recommendations therein
With the MTR recommendations the project is working on updating the activities and Outputs Subsequently related indicators will be reflected in the project log frame Technology related issues will be addressed as well during this adaptive management process Industry preferences are in biomass fired conventional boilers with modern controlling and feeding systems with cogeneration and trigeneration options industrial dryers etc
In order to select committed partners for demonstration projects Project has initiated discussion with the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce not gone ahead with newspaper advertisement as proposed earlier as the advertisement by SLSEA for registering supply chain operators received a poor response Once the technology concern is addressed to project expects to work with the industry on assisting in feasibility studies and technology demonstration

comment.narrative: Report on pros and cons on fossil fuel subsidies published by year 1 resulting in a at least one policy paper and presentation to Treasury officials through SLSEA

The fossil fuel subsidies existed during project development period has been withdrawn But there was no firm fossil fuel pricing methodology nor policy governing it in operation but fuel prices have been brought up as a political issue Project has been working on obtaining services of a suitable consultant to carry out a study but this volatile situation was not the opportune time
The establishment of the new government in January 2015 the fossil fuel prices have been changed and the government is planning to introduce transparent cost reflective pricing formula for fossil fuel as well Now the country is again at a verge of parliamentary election through which a new government will be established The subsidy effect if any will be analyzed to take appropriate future actions when the current scenario is stabilized

Industry is very keen on biomass energy option and many companies have already installed plants without project inputs However project expects to introduce demand driven modern bioenergy technologies as demonstrations after the conclusion of the project consolidation

With reference to 2014 PIR the delayed start of the project was explained and Considering the time factor for developing a certification scheme during the project lifetime Lead Technical Officer of the project decided to go for a process of developing criteria and indicators for sustainably produced fuel wood Through a LoA Sri Lanka Standards Institution SLSI was assigned to develop criteria and Indicators for sustainably produce fuel wood First working group meeting held in May 2015 to draft the initial document This will be reviewed and updated during the next working group meeting It is expected to initiate the pilot the scheme by mid2016
At the time the project was designed the Coconut Cultivation Board operated a subsidy scheme of LKR 4000ac for growing Gliricidia in coconut lands However in 2011 this subsidy scheme had been withdrawn due to poor uptake by the farmers
During the Inception Workshop CCB had agreed to revive a projectsupported pilot subsidy scheme for Gliricidia cultivation in the coconut triangle districts of Gampaha Kurunegala and Puttalam There was no followup on this initiative and the CCB had not launched this programme
The project is following up with CCB who agreed to explore the possibility of incorporating Gliricidia as a component in its animal husbandry subsidy scheme and to explore ways of mobilizing the communities under the CCBs Kapruka Societies to enhance Gliricidia cultivation

description.narrative: Improved confidence among industrial and banking sector on the feasibility stability and economic benefits of sustainable fuel wood supply chains
Number of supply chains developed in a feasible way

comment.narrative: Supply chains meet constraints
At least six supply chains developed that are sustainable on the longer term

The study on the current status of biomass energy has been concluded This study has recorded that there are well established supply chains feeding industrial zones of Biyagama Horana and Seethawaka supplying 820 tons of biomass per day as well as several large industries located outside industrial zones and tea factories Fuel is supplied as mainly wood logs wood chips and saw dustrice husk Several facilities that convert wood logs to chips also established to feed the demand Prices of different types of fuel and supply mechanisms have been recorded The major concerns now prevail in the industry are sustainability of the wood supplies modes of optimizing existing chains to get the best outcome from the resources involved and identification of further mechanizations to improve the efficiency of operation and quality of the product This information will be used to plan future activities in a more focussed manner
SLSEA has published a newspaper and web advertisement to get supply chain operators listed with them but received a poor response However with the Trainings and awareness activities conducted the project has identified key players However smaller grass root level organizations need more attention and that gap will be filled by the Trainers trained at the TOT on supply chain development SLSEA is planning activities on this regard

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Indicator 1: Manual is available to train government officers and volunteer on Climate and Disaster sensitive Village resource Management Plans
Indicator 2: Number of Grama Nildari -level mobilisers train on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village DP/ VRMP process
Indicator 3: No of stakeholder groups reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at national, district and village levels
Indicator 4: Number of government departments providing regular in-house training programs embedded with climate resilient planning tools.
Indicator 5: Number of people having access (quantity, quality and time) to water throughout year

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: Currently no manual available Baseline 2: 0 Baseline 3: 90% of the stakeholder groups do have zero awareness on climate change risks and adaptation measures. stakeholder groups -Officers of National Planning, Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Economic Development -Divi Neguma Task Force at National and District level -District Planning Units -Divisional Planning Units -Village mobilisers-communities in risk prone GN units Baseline 4: Except Irrigation Department all the other line department and ministries do not have climate resilient planning tools in regular training programs adequately Baseline 5: the beneficiaries living in the command areas of the targeted 15 tanks do not have year-round access to quality water
Target 1:Manual is available Target 2: 0 Target 3: 2 stakeholder groups increase awareness on climate change risk Target 4: 0 Target 5: at least 7,500 people have access to water throughout the year

Result 1:Resilinet village framework was developed in collaboration with a broad range of stakeholders under the leadership of Ministry of Disaster Management. Training manual was developed based on the resilient village framework. Technical focus of the resilient village development planning training manual is to reduce the vulnerability.
Result 2: 0 Result 3: 2 stakeholder groups namely Department of Agrarian Development and Provincial Department of Agriculture (160 people) reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at district, divisional and village levels. Target 1: Manual is available Target 2: 200 mobilizers trained on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village Development Planning/ VRMP process Target 3: 5 stakeholder groups (115 individuals) Target 4: 2 departments provide in-house training programmes embedded with climate change adaptation Target 5: at least 17,500 people have access to water throughout the year

Result1: Resilient village framework was developed in collaboration with a broad range of stakeholders under the leadership of Ministry of Disaster Management. Training manual was developed based on the resilient village framework. Technical focus of the resilient village development planning training manual is to reduce the vulnerability. Completed by 2015
Result 2: 300 Grama Niladari level mobilizers train on participatory climate and disaster sensitive Village Development Planning/ VRMP and risk sensitive development planning (Grame Niladharis, Development Officers, Samurdhi Officers, Social Service Officers, Village Leaders). As a result of training, they already produced 45 climate resilient village development plans
Result 3: 5 stakeholder groups namely Department of Agrarian Development, Provincial Department of Agriculture, Divisional Secretariats, District Secretariats, SEMA (120 people) reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at National, Provincial, district, divisional and village levels
Result 4: 2 departments viz (a) Provincial Department of Agriculture - North Western Province and (b) Divisional Secretariats – North Western Province providing regular in-house training programs embedded with climate resilient planning tools including climate resilient agriculture development strategic plan, climatic vulnerability maps and resilient village framework.
Result 5: 18,000 people have access to water throughout the year in terms of quantity, quality and timely manner through rehabilitating 34 tanks. Rehabilitation of 34 tanks also improved the water levels of the ground wells.

1). 0 (Energy sector Data Management System is being developed and this system to be integrated with national EnerGIS web-based data collection system. This system is to be introduced to the provincial councils after the necessary training programmes are completed. This is planned for Q4 2017, Q 12018) 2). 46 (Energy full MACC analysis has been completed, and this analysis includes 46 technology-options in the sector. Multi-Criteria Assessment is being performed for the energy sector combining MACC analysis and other socio-economic factors for prioritizing NAMAs) 3). 121 biogas units, 14 solar PV systems, 24 High Efficiency Motors (Approximately another 80-100 biogas units are under development/construction phase. However, small scale biogas programme has not been progressing as anticipated. Therefore, the project is now also promoting medium-large scale units under the programme. Similarly, the expected energy saving and corresponding GHG emission reduction from High Efficiency Motor application in Tea sector is difficult to be realized and Variable Frequency Drives (VFD) as a technology alternative has been considered. This efficiency motor programme has now been replaced with VFD in the same sector, and the procurement approval of 730 VFD units for 95 tea factories has been given. It is expected that these VFD units will be installed in Q1 of 2018. From 14 pilot units, it is found that the Domestic solar PV with battery storage is a costlier GHG emission mitigation technology, and the concept of battery energy storage needs reconsideration. Rooftop solar for government sector (mainly rural schools) is now being considered as an alternative) 4). 0 5). 0 (MRVing protocols and methodologies for the initially selected three technologies; i.e biogas, domestic solar PV, and efficiency motors have been developed. 1. 2 of 3Case flow Management Committees (CFM) committees established 2. Priority cases identified in area model 01 3. Draft Legal Aid Policy ready for review with key Stakeholders 4. Formation of special mediation boards for land cases 5. Sector Coordination plan identified 6. 02 more pieces of legislature have been consolidated and translated

1. Case Flow Management Committee established in 1 area model. 2. Priority cases were not identified in the area model as the consultation processes continued through out 2015 and the study to assess the blocks in the case flow faced several challenges to getting off the ground. 3. The Draft Legal Aid Policy has been finalized and provided to the Ministry of Justice to prepare for submission to the Cabinet of Ministers. 4. Following the gazette being issued calling for the establishment of special land mediation boards, UNDP supported the primary step of raising awareness on the gazette and role of the boards in the pilot districts. This is a pre-requisite before calling for nominations of individuals to serve on the special land mediation boards. UNDP worked collaboratively with the Asia Foundation in this regard as TAF is preparing to provide training for the Board members, once established. 6. Translation and consolidation of the Evidence Ordinance and Judicature Act was initiated in 2015 and the process is on-going.

1. Indicator not applicable for 2016. 2. Support the clearance of backlog Child Abuse, Narcotics and Pubic Complaints cases through support to the Attorney General's Department 3. National Legal Aid Policy approved 4. Indicator not applicable for 2016. 5. Indicator not applicable for 2016. 6. Undertake the Translation and consolidation of the Civil Procedure Code, and complete the work initiated in 2015 for the Evidence Ordinance and Judicature Act Other- a) Provide legal aid support in Prisons

2. 1624 Child abuse cases, 811 narcotics cases and 142 Public complaints cases cleared as backlog 3. National Legal Aid Policy approved by the Cabinet of Ministers and Strategic Plan Developed. Policy also translated in to Tamil and Sinhala languages. 6. Judicature Act, Evidence Ordinance and Civil Procedure Code translated and consolidated. Other- a) Support provided focusing on: 224 legal advice cases, 32 legal aid clinics, 40 bail cases in the High Court, 6 Bail cases in the Court of Appeal and 56 Bail cases in the Magistrates Court
The December 2016 Programme Board meeting decided to bring the Project to a close on 31 December 2016, and therefore there are no targets set for 2017.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. 2014 conducted National Ozone day celebration through the project. Made aware 950 individual from different institution on protection and restoration Ozone Depleting Substances. Theme was “30 years world together “. Supported to enhance awareness on school children through art competition too.
1. Celebration of national Ozone Day ( September 16 th is the national Ozone day )

1.Key event of the 2015 national zone day celebration was to open a Reclamation Centre with a view of purifying recovered gas from air conditioners and refrigeration equipment of the commercial sector. Made aware directly around 1300 individual from different institution on protection and restoration Ozone Depleting Substances. School drama coemption, sharing leaf lets and printed T- shirts are some of the activities carried out to enhance the awareness. Indirectly reached to more wider groups of people through radio programme too.
1. Celebration of national Ozone Day

1. Donation of 12 wheel chairs for eye and cancer hospitals was the flag event of this year’s National Ozone Day Celebration to make people aware on the impact of Ozone Depleting Substance and occurrence of eye cataract. Reached to larger number of people through both radio and Television. Reached to school children through art completions also was taken place. Directly reached around 1500 individuals.
1. Celebration of national Ozone Day

1. Ozone day was celebrated on 18 of September,2017, at the bar reef in Kalpitiya. This year, 2000 mangrove seedlings were planted at the lagoon, as part of an awareness campaign on the importance of mangroves for the restoration of the ozone and protection of the environment.

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. 0 3. 0 4. UNDP provided an orientation for new Parliamentarians in 2015. UNDP commenced its support to Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery or Corruption (CIABOC) end November 2015, for commemoration of International Anti-Corruption Day. 5. 0

1.: 1 2.: 1 3.: 1 4. No target set for this year 5. Technical assistance to Parliament and CIABOC for key policy, institutional and systems reforms identified by the National Unity Government in 2015.

1. Policy Lab - informal coordination mechanism with Prime Minister's Office, National Planning Department (NPD), Department of Project Management and Monitoring (DPMM), Biodiversity Sri Lanka (private sector platform, part of Ceylon Chambers of Commerce), Coordinating Secretariat for Science Technology and Innovation (COSTI), Lirne Asia, UNDP. Headed by the government. To establish and run the Policy Innovation Lab.
2. - Support to the Police Commission – support to the Future Policing conference, which engaged high-level Police Officials and Academics from the SAARC region, enabling knowledge sharing of different strategies adopted by countries in the region to strengthen the role of the police and the relationship between the police and the citizens, as well as reflection on the need for police reforms in Sri Lanka. - Foresight and Innovations Summit – organized with GOSL, involving 4 governments and resource persons for 4 other countries. - JICA and NPD training – for capacity building for provincial development planners using foresight as a value addition tool for development planning. Involved resource people from India.
3. - COSTI Idea Board – strengthening government’s innovation dashboard, to engage citizens’ ideas on development issues. Pilot phase complete and tested. Looking into cost-sharing model, with COSTI committing funds to further develop this.

1.: 1mutli-staekholder mechanism is facilitated by the UNDP during 2017. UNDP facilitated the establishment of a coordination mechanism for the Ministry of Mass Media to engage with civil society organizations (CSOs) working on Right to Information based in Colombo, which would be extended to the provinces over time. 2.: 8 recommendations have been recommended. Of the 8 recommendations: 4 accelerators for achieving the SDGs prescribed in the RIA; 3 main recommendations from the 2017 budget analysis for the Parliamentary Select Committee on Sustainable Development; Review of legislation in conflict with the RTI legal regime: 105 pieces of legislation were identified, impacting on reactive and proactive information disclosure. 8 pieces of legislation were prioritized as requiring urgent amendment. 3. 1 initiative has been established in collaboration with the government incorporating South-South Cooperation. As part of its technical assistance on implementing the Right to Information (RTI) to the Ministry of Mass Media, UNDP commissioned the Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative (CHRI), an international non-governmental organisation, to provide comparative experience and good practice from the region and beyond. As part of this collaboration, the CHRI authored a Guidance Note on Operationalizing the Right to Information Act in Sri Lanka: Comparative Experience and Good Practice. The note draws on comparative experience from South Asia and other jurisdictions with a history of implementing similar laws to provide solutions to some of the challenges that might arise in implementing Sri Lanka’s RTI Act. In addition, CHRI also provided technical inputs to the Review of Legislation in Conflict with the RTI Act in Sri Lanka. 4.: No target set for 2017 5. With the Community Forestry Project in particular, all stakeholders (the government, the donor and UNDP) conduct quarterly missions to the field, and discuss issues, challenges and take corrective actions. Furthermore, before project board meetings, project teams conduct reviews to assess results and challenges and document learnings.

1. - Strategic analysis/assessment - Secured the technical advisory support of a Senior Conflict advisor based in New York on developing UNDP Sri Lanka’s peacebuilding strategy and based on this, a framework for UNDP’s engagement with the Peacebuilding Fund. 4 recommendations were provided at the end of the mission. - Mid-term Review of the Country Programme Document – 45 recommendations on policy, institutional and systems reforms within the UNDP.
2. Urgent work priorities through the year were not conducive to initiating discussions around establishing a mechanism on learning. However, during the Mid-term Review (MTR) of the Country Programme Document, a core group across clusters and units was identified to regularly engage throughout the process. In addition, the broader group of staff was engaged in key steps, such as sharing of initial findings and recommendations for feedback, as well as identification of potential entry points for the new country programme based on lessons learned.

The planning process and inception phase for this project took a considerably longer period than previously envisaged. Thus as at end December, progress towards outputs had not been achieved. A strategic work plan has been developed and key stakeholders have been consulted. Work in relation to this will begin early next year.
